source.name: City of Philadelphia Streets Department
source.notes: Based on official City of Philadelphia recycling program guidelines. Single-stream blue bin recycling with weekly collection. Empty paint cans and aerosol cans are accepted.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Replace the cap
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes water, soda, juice, and sports drink bottles
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still inside
Don't crush; caps should be replaced

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Replace the cap
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes milk jugs, juice jugs, and detergent jugs
commonMistakes: Don't leave product inside
Don't include jugs that held hazardous chemicals (pesticides, etc.)

materials.name: Detergent and shampoo bottles
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Replace the cap or pump
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Pump and spray tops can stay on the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with product still inside

materials.name: Pump and spray bottles
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Leave the pump or spray mechanism attached
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Plastic spray and pump bottles from cleaning products are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles that held hazardous materials (pesticides, etc.)

materials.name: 5-gallon buckets
instructions: Empty and rinse thoroughly
Remove any non-plastic handles if possible
Place in or next to BLUE recycling bin
notes: Philadelphia accepts 5-gallon plastic buckets in recycling
Must be empty and clean
commonMistakes: Don't include buckets that still contain paint or chemicals
Don't include buckets with heavy residue that won't rinse out

materials.name: Hard plastic food containers
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Must be hard/rigid plastic, not flexible film or styrofoam
Includes yogurt cups, deli containers, butter tubs, and hard plastic takeout containers
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam containers; those go in the trash
Don't include flexible plastic pouches or bags

materials.name: Bottle caps
instructions: Keep caps attached to their bottles whenever possible
Loose metal bottle caps can be placed inside an aluminum can and crimped shut
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Both plastic and metal bottle caps are accepted in Philadelphia
Attaching caps to bottles prevents them from falling through sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't throw loose small caps in; they can fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: No need to crush cans
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still inside

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes all food and pet food cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue; rinse them out

materials.name: Empty paint cans
instructions: Ensure the can is completely empty or has only dried residue
Remove the lid and place it separately in the bin
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Philadelphia accepts empty paint cans in curbside recycling
Can must be fully empty with only dry residue remaining
Cans with wet or liquid paint must go to a Sanitation Convenience Center
commonMistakes: Don't put cans with wet or liquid paint in recycling
Don't include spray paint cans here; see empty aerosol cans

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
instructions: Ensure the can is completely empty (no hissing when you press the nozzle)
Do NOT puncture the can
Leave the nozzle on
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Philadelphia accepts empty aerosol cans in curbside recycling
Must be fully depressurized and empty
commonMistakes: Don't recycle aerosol cans that still have product or pressure inside
Don't puncture aerosol cans; this is dangerous

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up small pieces into a larger ball (at least 2 inches)
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food that won't come off
Don't include foil-lined paper or foil-backed insulation

materials.name: Aluminum pie tins and trays
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes disposable aluminum baking pans and pie plates
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled trays that can't be cleaned

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Remove metal lids (recycle lids separately)
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: All colors of glass bottles and jars are accepted
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include window glass, mirrors, ceramics, or Pyrex
Don't include drinking glasses or light bulbs
Don't include broken glass; wrap it and put in trash for safety

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Keep dry
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Inserts and supplements can stay with the newspaper
commonMistakes: Don't include newspapers that are wet or heavily soiled

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Remove any plastic wrap
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Glossy and coated paper magazines are accepted
Includes catalogs, booklets, and brochures
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or moldy magazines

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
instructions: Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Window envelopes are OK; the small plastic window is accepted
Includes all paper mail, flyers, and advertisements
commonMistakes: Don't include padded or bubble-lined mailers; those go in the trash

materials.name: Writing and office paper
instructions: Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes white and colored paper
Staples and paper clips are OK; no need to remove them
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues; those go in the trash
Don't include waxed or plastic-coated paper

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten the bag
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes brown grocery bags and lunch bags
Must be clean and dry
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags that are wet or heavily food-soiled

materials.name: Paperback books
instructions: Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Paperback books are accepted in Philadelphia recycling
Consider donating books in good condition before recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include hardcover books; remove the hard covers first or donate them

materials.name: Non-metallic greeting cards
instructions: Remove any metallic decorations, ribbons, or batteries
Place paper card in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Only non-metallic, non-glittered cards are accepted
Cards with batteries (musical cards) must have batteries removed first
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cards with glitter, metallic finishes, or foil
Don't forget to remove batteries from musical cards

materials.name: Corrugated cardboard boxes
instructions: Break down and flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (styrofoam, bubble wrap, air pillows)
Place in or next to BLUE recycling bin
notes: Must be flattened
Remove any styrofoam or plastic packing inside
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated cardboard (some produce boxes)
Don't leave packing peanuts or styrofoam inside

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Remove any leftover food or liners
Flatten the box
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Philadelphia accepts clean pizza boxes in recycling
Light grease staining is OK; heavy grease or stuck-on cheese is not
commonMistakes: Don't include the box if it has a lot of stuck-on cheese or food
Don't forget to remove any leftover pizza or liners

materials.name: Paper towel and toilet paper rolls
instructions: Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Cardboard tubes from paper towels, toilet paper, and wrapping paper are all accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include the paper towels themselves; those go in the trash

materials.name: Cardboard egg cartons
instructions: Remove any remaining egg shells
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Only cardboard/paper egg cartons are recyclable
Styrofoam egg cartons go in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons; those go in the trash
Don't include egg cartons with heavy egg residue

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Replace the cap if it has one
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes gable-top (refrigerated) and shelf-stable cartons
Philadelphia accepts all food and beverage cartons
commonMistakes: Don't leave liquid inside
Don't flatten shelf-stable cartons; they have a foil layer and sorting machines detect shape

materials.name: Soup and wine cartons
instructions: Empty, rinse, and let dry
Replace the cap if it has one
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Includes Tetra Pak and other shelf-stable cartons
commonMistakes: Don't leave liquid inside

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT place in recycling bin; they jam sorting machinery
Place in regular trash
Better: return clean, dry bags to grocery store collection bins
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in Philadelphia recycling
Many grocery stores have bag collection bins near the entrance
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; they tangle in sorting equipment
Don't bag your recyclables in plastic bags; put items loose in the bin

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Styrofoam is not recyclable in Philadelphia
Includes foam cups, food containers, meat trays, and protective packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't confuse hard plastic containers with styrofoam; hard plastic is recyclable

materials.name: Packing peanuts
instructions: Place in regular trash
Alternatively, offer them for reuse on community boards or to shipping stores
notes: Not recyclable in Philadelphia curbside programs
Some shipping stores will accept clean packing peanuts for reuse
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't mix with recyclable materials

materials.name: Plastic straws
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Straws are too small and lightweight for sorting machinery
Consider switching to reusable straws
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; they fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Coffee cup lids
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Disposable coffee cup lids are not accepted in Philadelphia recycling
Too small and lightweight for sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't confuse with larger rigid plastic container lids (which may be recyclable)

materials.name: Plastic cutlery
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Plastic utensils are not recyclable in Philadelphia
Consider carrying reusable utensils
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Waxed paper and wax-coated cardboard
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Wax coating prevents paper fibers from being recycled
Includes waxed produce boxes, freezer paper, and wax-coated paper
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with plain paper or cardboard, which are recyclable
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in regular trash
Do NOT place in recycling bin
notes: Disposable coffee cups have a plastic lining that makes them non-recyclable
Some coffee shops offer discounts for bringing a reusable cup
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; the plastic lining contaminates paper recycling
Don't confuse the cardboard sleeve with the cup; the sleeve can be recycled separately

materials.name: Window glass and mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard for safety
Place in regular trash
For large panes, take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
notes: Window glass, mirrors, and plate glass are chemically different from bottle glass
They cannot be recycled with bottles and jars
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; different melting point than container glass
Don't confuse with glass bottles and jars, which are recyclable

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: Wrap in paper or place in original packaging
Place in regular trash
notes: LED and incandescent bulbs go in the trash
CFL (compact fluorescent) bulbs contain mercury and should go to a Sanitation Convenience Center
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't put CFL bulbs in the trash; take them to a Convenience Center

materials.name: Fluorescent and CFL bulbs
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center for proper disposal
notes: Fluorescent bulbs contain mercury and are considered hazardous waste
Sanitation Convenience Centers accept them for free
commonMistakes: Don't throw in the trash; mercury is a hazardous pollutant
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling
Tape the terminals of lithium and 9V batteries to prevent fires
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
notes: All battery types are accepted at Sanitation Convenience Centers
Some retailers (Home Depot, Lowe's, Staples) also accept rechargeable batteries
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in the trash; they can cause fires in garbage trucks
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Erase personal data from devices before disposal
notes: Pennsylvania law prohibits putting electronics in the trash
Sanitation Convenience Centers accept electronics for free
Some retailers offer electronics recycling (Best Buy, Staples)
commonMistakes: Don't put in the trash; it's illegal in PA
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Liquid paint
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Keep in original labeled container with lid secured
notes: Liquid and wet paint is hazardous waste
Empty or fully dried paint cans can go in BLUE recycling bin
To dry out small amounts of latex paint: add kitty litter, let dry, then trash the solid
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in the trash or recycling

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or pour down drains
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Keep in a sealed, leak-proof container
notes: Many auto parts stores (AutoZone, O'Reilly) also accept used motor oil
commonMistakes: Don't pour down a drain or onto the ground
Don't put in the trash

materials.name: Pesticides and household chemicals
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or pour down drains
Keep in original labeled container
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
notes: Includes pesticides, herbicides, pool chemicals, solvents, and other toxic chemicals
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or into storm sewers
Don't mix different chemicals together

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or recycling
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
notes: Pressurized tanks are dangerous in trash and recycling machinery
Some propane suppliers offer tank exchange programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in the trash; pressurized containers can explode in trucks
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Do NOT place in trash or flush down the toilet
Use a police department drug take-back box
Or take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
notes: Many Philadelphia police districts have 24/7 medication drop-off boxes
DEA National Take-Back events are held periodically
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications; they contaminate water supply
Don't put in the trash where children or pets could find them

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place leaves in paper bags or open containers (NOT plastic bags)
Bundle branches (under 4 feet long, under 6 inches diameter)
Set out on your scheduled yard waste collection day
notes: Philadelphia collects yard waste on a seasonal schedule (typically spring and fall)
Check phila.gov for your collection schedule
Do NOT use plastic bags for yard waste
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in plastic bags; use paper bags or leave loose in a can
Don't mix yard waste with regular trash
Don't put out yard waste outside the scheduled collection period

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Place in regular trash
Consider home composting as an alternative
notes: Philadelphia does NOT have a curbside composting program
Some community gardens and farmers markets accept food scraps
Bennett Compost and other private services offer residential pickup for a fee
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the BLUE recycling bin; they contaminate recyclables

materials.name: Paper towels and napkins
instructions: Place in regular trash
notes: Paper towels and napkins are not recyclable due to food contamination and short fibers
If Philadelphia had composting, these would be compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Wrap and seal used diapers
Place in regular trash
notes: Disposable diapers are not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Ceramics, pottery, and Pyrex
instructions: Wrap broken pieces carefully
Place in regular trash
notes: Ceramics and heat-resistant glass (Pyrex) are chemically different from recyclable bottle glass
They contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; they ruin glass recycling batches
Don't confuse with glass bottles and jars

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable clothing to local thrift stores or donation bins
Damaged textiles can go to textile recycling bins (found at many locations)
As a last resort, bag and place in regular trash
notes: Philadelphia has textile recycling bins throughout the city
Even damaged, stained, or torn textiles can be recycled into rags and insulation
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't throw away wearable clothing; donate it first

materials.name: Scrap metal and appliances
instructions: Small metal items: place next to BLUE recycling bin on collection day
Large appliances: take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Or schedule a bulk pickup through 311 or phila.gov
notes: Philadelphia Streets Department collects large items on request
Refrigerators and AC units must have refrigerant removed by a certified technician before disposal
commonMistakes: Don't leave large appliances on the curb without scheduling a pickup
Don't put small appliances in the BLUE bin; place next to it

materials.name: Mattresses and furniture
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup through 311 or phila.gov
Or take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Do NOT leave on the curb without scheduling
notes: Bulk item pickup is available through the Streets Department
Consider donating usable furniture to local charities
commonMistakes: Don't dump on the curb; illegal dumping carries fines in Philadelphia
Don't block sidewalks or streets with discarded furniture

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Or return to a tire retailer when purchasing new tires
notes: Tires are not collected with regular trash or recycling
Limit of 4 tires per visit at Convenience Centers (off the rim)
commonMistakes: Don't put in the trash or leave on the curb
Don't illegally dump tires; fines apply

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Let cool completely
Pour into a sealed, non-recyclable container (e.g., old milk carton)
Place sealed container in regular trash
NEVER pour down the drain
notes: Pouring grease down the drain causes sewer blockages ('fatbergs')
Some Sanitation Convenience Centers accept cooking oil for recycling into biodiesel
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the drain or toilet
Don't put liquid grease directly in the trash; contain it first

materials.name: Padded mailers and bubble wrap
instructions: Place in regular trash
notes: Padded mailers combine paper and plastic/foam, making them non-recyclable
Bubble wrap can be returned to grocery store plastic bag collection bins
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin
Don't confuse with plain paper envelopes, which are recyclable

materials.name: Hardcover books
instructions: Donate to a library, school, or thrift store
If not donatable, remove the hard cover and recycle the paper pages in the BLUE bin
Hard covers go in the trash
notes: Philadelphia Free Library accepts book donations
Consider using Little Free Libraries in your neighborhood
commonMistakes: Don't put a whole hardcover book in the recycling bin; the binding glue and cover board cause problems

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper in a paper bag and staple or tape shut
Place the bag in the BLUE recycling bin
notes: Loose shredded paper can jam machinery and blow away
Containing it in a paper bag keeps it together through the sorting process
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper directly in the bin; it scatters
Don't use a plastic bag to contain shredded paper

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Remove the inner plastic liner/bag
Flatten the box
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Thin cardboard (paperboard) food boxes are accepted
Includes cereal, pasta, cracker, and snack boxes
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag; that goes in the trash
Don't include frozen food boxes; they have a moisture coating and go in the trash

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
instructions: Place in regular trash
notes: Frozen food boxes have a moisture-resistant coating that prevents recycling
This includes ice cream cartons, frozen dinner boxes, and frozen vegetable bags
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; the coating contaminates paper recycling
Don't confuse with regular cereal/food boxes, which ARE recyclable

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in regular trash
Consider donating to dry cleaners or thrift stores
notes: Hangers tangle in recycling machinery regardless of material
Wire, plastic, and wooden hangers all go in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; they jam sorting equipment

materials.name: String lights and holiday lights
instructions: Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Some hardware stores accept them seasonally
notes: String lights contain copper wire that can be recycled, but they tangle in sorting machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; they wrap around equipment
Don't put in the trash if you can drop them off for recycling

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in a rigid, puncture-proof container (e.g., laundry detergent bottle) labeled 'SHARPS'
When full, tape the container shut
Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center or participating pharmacy
notes: Never put loose sharps in the trash or recycling
Some pharmacies accept sharps containers
commonMistakes: Don't throw loose needles in the trash; sanitation workers can be injured
Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin

materials.name: Smoke detectors
instructions: Take to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Some contain small amounts of radioactive material (americium-241)
notes: Ionization smoke detectors contain radioactive material and require special disposal
Check if the manufacturer offers a mail-back program
commonMistakes: Don't put in the trash or recycling

materials.name: Thermal receipts
instructions: Place in regular trash
notes: Thermal paper (shiny, slick receipts) contains BPA and is not recyclable
Choose digital receipts when possible
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE recycling bin; BPA contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Rigid plastic clamshells
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE recycling bin
notes: Rigid clear hinged plastic containers are accepted
Must be hard plastic, not foam
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam clamshells; those go in the trash

recycle: BLUE BIN: Newspapers, magazines, junk mail, envelopes, writing paper, paper bags
BLUE BIN: Paperback books, non-metallic greeting cards
BLUE BIN: Plastic bottles, jugs, hard plastic containers, 5-gallon buckets
BLUE BIN: Detergent/shampoo bottles, pump/spray bottles
BLUE BIN: Aluminum/steel/tin cans, empty paint cans, empty aerosol cans
BLUE BIN: Aluminum foil, pie tins, metal bottle caps
BLUE BIN: All glass bottles and jars (empty, rinsed, dry)
BLUE BIN: Flattened corrugated cardboard, clean pizza boxes, paper towel rolls
BLUE BIN: Cardboard egg cartons, cereal/food boxes
BLUE BIN: Milk, juice, soup, and wine cartons (empty, rinsed, dry)
compost: No curbside composting program in Philadelphia
Yard waste is collected separately on a seasonal schedule (paper bags only, no plastic bags)
Consider home composting or private composting services (e.g., Bennett Compost)
Some community gardens and farmers markets accept food scraps
trash: Plastic bags, plastic film, plastic wrap
Plastic straws, coffee cup lids, plastic cutlery

recycle: Plastic bags, film, and wrap; they jam sorting machinery
Styrofoam; not recyclable in Philadelphia
Packing peanuts
Plastic straws; too small for sorting equipment
Coffee cup lids; too small for sorting equipment
Plastic cutlery
Waxed paper and wax-coated cardboard
Disposable coffee cups (plastic-lined)
Frozen food boxes (moisture-coated)
Window glass, mirrors, ceramics, Pyrex
Light bulbs of any type
Batteries
Hangers
Thermal receipts (contain BPA)
Padded mailers and bubble wrap
compost: Philadelphia does not offer curbside composting
Food scraps go in regular trash unless you use a private composting service

tips: Philadelphia uses SINGLE-STREAM recycling: all recyclables go in one BLUE bin
Empty, rinse, and dry containers before recycling; they don't need to be spotless
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space in your blue bin
Clean pizza boxes ARE accepted; just remove leftover food
Empty paint cans and empty aerosol cans ARE accepted in the blue bin
5-gallon plastic buckets ARE recyclable in Philadelphia
Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant; NEVER put them in the blue bin
Don't bag your recyclables in plastic bags; put items loose in the bin
Return plastic bags to grocery store collection bins instead
Bottle caps should stay on their bottles; loose caps fall through sorting screens
Shredded paper goes in a paper bag, stapled shut, then in the blue bin
Yard waste has a separate seasonal collection; use paper bags, not plastic
Philadelphia does NOT have curbside composting; food scraps go in trash
Take hazardous waste (batteries, paint, chemicals) to a Sanitation Convenience Center
Schedule bulk pickups (furniture, appliances) through 311 or phila.gov
When in doubt, put it in the trash; contamination ruins entire recycling loads

locations.name: Sanitation Convenience Center  Northwest
locations.address: Domino Lane & Umbria St, Philadelphia, PA 19128
locations.notes: Open Wednesday through Sunday, 8 AM6 PM. Closed Monday and Tuesday. Philadelphia residents only; proof of residency may be required.

locations.name: Sanitation Convenience Center  Northeast
locations.address: State Rd & Ashburner St, Philadelphia, PA 19136
locations.notes: Open Wednesday through Sunday, 8 AM6 PM. Closed Monday and Tuesday. Philadelphia residents only; proof of residency may be required.

locations.name: Sanitation Convenience Center  South
locations.notes: Open Wednesday through Sunday, 8 AM6 PM. Closed Monday and Tuesday. Philadelphia residents only; proof of residency may be required.
